items.title: Sherrone Moore charged with stalking, home invasion after being fired as Michigan football coach
items.summary_auto: Sherrone Moore, who was abruptly fired this week as the University of Michigan football coach, was charged Friday with three crimes including home invasion and stalking a person he had dated, prosecutors said.

items.title: Government inks $753M deal for 6 Bombardier Global 6500 jets to replace Challengers
items.summary_auto: The federal government announced Friday that it's buying six new Global 6500 jets from Bombardier to replace its existing fleet of four CC-144 Challengers.

items.title: Who is Mark Sutcliffe? Ottawa's mayor stumps Jeopardy! champ
items.summary_auto: Mark Sutcliffe might be a household name in Ottawa, but when he appeared in a Jeopardy! clue Thursday evening, the reigning champion was stumped.

items.title: House Democrats release photos of Trump, Clinton and Andrew from Epstein's estate
items.summary_auto: House Democrats released a selection of photos from the estate of Jeffrey Epstein on Friday, including some of Donald Trump, Bill Clinton and the former Prince Andrew.

items.title: Bloyce Thompson sworn in as new P.E.I. premier, 1 day after Rob Lantz resigns
Blue Jays renew president and CEO Mark Shapiro on 5-year contract
items.summary_auto: Toronto Blue Jays president and chief executive officer Mark Shapiro has signed a five-year contract renewal, Rogers Communications announced Friday.

items.title: Edmonton Oilers trade Stuart Skinner, Brett Kulak to Pittsburgh Penguins
items.summary_auto: The Edmonton Oilers have finally made a move in net, trading the hometown netminder Stuart Skinner to the Pittsburgh Penguins for goalie Tristan Jarry.

items.title: Clair Obscur cleans up at 2025 Game Awards, wins game of the year
items.summary_auto: French indie game Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 had 12 nominations in total and took home nine awards. Mario Kart, Battlefield 6 and the TV adaptation of The Last Of Us also took home prizes.

items.title: Calgary Transit shuttle bus bursts into flames on busy road
items.summary_auto: A Calgary Transit shuttle bus went up in flames Friday morning on Nose Hill Drive near Stoney Trail in northwest Calgary.

items.title: Venezuela vexes Trump but rightward trend across Americas could help U.S. national security strategy
items.summary_auto: The favourite in Chile's election on Sunday is the right-wing José Antonio Kast. A Kast victory would be the latest rightward political shift in South America, as U.S. President Donald Trump and the White House try to coax or force the socialist leader of Venezuela from office.

items.title: At least 12 Palestinians dead or missing in Gaza as devastation from floods spreads
items.summary_auto: Hundreds of thousands of displaced Gazans face flooding from heavy rains, and materials for shelters and sandbags are not being allowed to enter the enclave, the UN International Organization for Migration said on Friday.

items.title: Indiana Republicans help defy Trump's push to redistrict House seats, including some who faced bomb threats
items.summary_auto: Indiana's Republican-led Senate has decisively rejected a redrawn congressional map desired by the White House that would have favoured their party. Two Republicans who received bomb threats amid the highly charged battle were among those voting against the measure.

items.title: Die-off of hundreds of birds something Manitoba hasn't experienced 'at this scale': biologist
items.summary_auto: At least 500 carcasses of birds, the majority of them Canadian geese, have been recovered near water streams in southern Manitoba over the last month — a die-off scientists say they have not witnessed in the province before and are attributing it to avian influenza.

items.title: Convicted human smuggler wants to self-represent in appeal, questions lawyer's conduct
items.summary_auto: A man convicted of human smuggling last year has asked a U.S. court to continue his appeal without a lawyer, in a case where a family from India froze to death near the Manitoba-U.S. border in 2022.

items.title: 'That was my granddaughter's voice': Senior suspects scammers used AI in Regina, Saskatoon
items.summary_auto: Jill Finn suspects thieves used AI to recreate her granddaughter's voice in the latest phone scam targeting seniors in Regina and Saskatoon.

items.title: N.S. mining claims spiked in 2025 following premier's push for resource development
items.summary_auto: Startups and international mining giants alike staked claims around Nova Scotia in high numbers after Premier Tim Houston unveiled his new open-arms approach to natural resource development, and local geologists and prospectors are abuzz.

items.title: The U.S. wants some visitors to submit 5 years of their social media history. How would that work?
Air Canada wins court battle to quash $2,000 payout to passenger for delayed luggage
items.summary_auto: Following an 11-month court battle, Air Canada has successfully overturned a Canadian Transportation Agency (CTA) decision requiring the airline to pay a passenger $2,079 for delayed baggage. But the case isn't over yet.

items.title: Turkey or lasagna? How some Canadians are celebrating the season amid rising costs
items.summary_auto: With food prices soaring — and meat in particular making a dent in wallets — some people may be planning a holiday meal that looks a little different this year.

items.title: Got empties? Finding a place to return them in Ontario is getting harder
items.summary_auto: Environmental activists say a recent agreement between the Beer Store and grocers puts the future of Ontario’s successful deposit return program at risk. Grocers with alcohol licences were expected to start accepting empties in the new year, but now they won’t have to after all.

items.title: Paul Mescal, Jessie Buckley-led Hamnet is a tragically beautiful tale of historical trickery
items.summary_auto: Chloé Zhao's Hamnet, which draws from William Shakespeare's personal and professional life, is a tragic window into the depths of despair.

items.title: A 6.7 magnitude earthquake causes small tsunami waves off northeastern Japan
items.summary_auto: A 6.7 magnitude earthquake shook northeastern Japan and caused small tsunami waves but no apparent damage Friday, days after a stronger quake in the same region.
